content.description: Possibly the best, certainly the most famous boulder problem at E-rock.   "Start sitting and climb the overhanging finger crack in the (left facing) corner", then climb the leftward slopey ledge to the finish jug.
content.protection: pad, spotter to keep heads from hitting the rock behind.
content.location:
Once in the corridor under the Acid boulder (Sci-Fi wall) this boulder blocks the West end. 

  Look under it

content.description: Climb the chimney following the fat protectable flake up to the chockstone. Pull a fun move over the chockstone to top out.
content.protection: Medium size pro to protect behind the fat flake. Small to medium size pieces to build an anchor. You may want something long to extend your anchor if you build it under Sander's Traverse.
content.location: Located in the chimney to the left of Solo Boulder and above Flake Crack. Look for the fat flake just past Chimney Crack. Chimney Crack is a far more exciting means of climbing the chimney. But Walnut Bowl is fun too.

content.description: This large boulder has a vast many vertical and horizontal variations. It is popular among soloists and sometimes guide services.
content.protection: Pad if desired. No bolts, anchors, or fixed pro. The landing is flat, but a little bit high ball. Guide services sometimes set the wall up for topropes, but it looks like quite a hassle.
content.location: Located above Sci-Fi Wall, next to (West of) Solo Boulder.

content.description: An easy lie back finger crack/flake. Follow it up to the top of the boulder pile and step off to the right. This flake is a fun boulder problem and is ideal for accessing the chimney which houses Chimney Crack and Walnut Bowl Factory.
content.protection: Pad if desired, flat landing. It will take small gear, maybe up to 0.75 if desired.
content.location: Located near the back Sci-Fi Wall. Below and past Innominate.

content.description:
Start in the chimney BEHIND Sander's Traverse. The namesake Drop Out will be on your left. If you look carefully before starting up the first chimney you can find a small conspicuous placement to protect the move across the Drop Out.  

  Move a short ways up the first chimney (behind Sander's) then step off to your left, over the Drop Out, onto a dike on the adjacent wall and slip into the chimney between Solo Boulder and Sander's Traverse. Scoot to your right and you'll find a protectable crack to follow until finding the stance near the top backside of Sander's. Again, step over the Drop Out and onto a ramp/chimney located behind Solo Boulder. Two or three moves later you'll top out on the North side of Solo boulder. It sounds confusing, but when you're looking up at it, it will seem obvious. This fun route goes for the most part unnoticed, but it's worth it. It's especially fun to link Flake Crack, Walnut Bowl or Chimney Crack, and Drop Out together.
content.protection: Small gear to protect the first step over the Drop Out, then medium size after that. The only crack found on top for a top anchor is huge and would require a BD5, 6 or Valley Giants. An easier option is to scramble up to the top of Solo boulder where multiple bolted anchors are found. Then use your rope to extend.
content.location: The namesake Drop Out is located in the cave between Solo Boulder and Sander's Traverse. Start climbing in the chimney behind Sander's Traverse.

content.description: Climb the crack starting from the chockstone. Reminiscent of the movie 127 Hours, this crack leaves from a chockstone wedged down inside a chimney. The crux is at the top, where it gets wider than hands. The landing is potentially very bad, especially if you fall and fail to land on the chockstone. Don't fall.
content.protection: Often bouldered, it can also be done roped. Since the landing is potentially catastrophic it's probably best to rope up for it.
content.location: Located in the chimney above and behind Sci-Fi Wall. The chockstone is found in the back of the chimney, between the backside of Sci-Fi Wall and Solo Boulder. Easiest to locate by finding Sander's Traverse, then walking thru the cave to the climbers right, exit the opposite side of the cave and walk/scramble until you see it.

content.description: Fun stemming chimney with great protection. Good for learning stemming technique.
content.protection: Medium cams for the climb, #4 C4 up top if you don't want to run it out (its easy terrain however). Smaller stuff for an anchor if you desire one. No fixed anchors. Somewhat long hike off (you may wish to bring approach shoes to get down).
content.location: After crawling under the Zanzibar boulder, continue  forward with the Sci-Fi wall on your left. You will reach a jumble of boulders. Climb under (easier if you are small) or over them while turning left. Chimney Crack is the obvious crack in the corridor.

content.description: Underneath and opposite the Acid boulder, and topping out to the Sanders patio, this alleyway is home to several very difficult face (and aid) climbs
